channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Activist to Stand Trial, Lawyer Says
item.description: Prosecutors have decided to put on trial a well-known human rights campaigner, Yang Maodong, on charges of disrupting public order, his lawyer said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Somalia: Kenyan Jets Bomb Militants
item.description: Kenyan fighter jets have attacked two bases belonging to the Shabab insurgent group in Somalia and killed at least 80 militants.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sudan: Christian Woman to Be Freed
item.description: A court canceled the death sentence against, Meriam Ibrahim, who was convicted of apostasy for marrying a Christian.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Meriam Ibrahim, 27, was convicted of apostasy for marrying a Christian.

item.title: Nigeria: Blast at Medical School Kills 8
item.description: An explosion on Monday at a medical school in Nigeria’s northern city of Kano killed at least eight people and wounded 12.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt: Conviction in Sectarianism Case
item.description: A court in the city of Minya convicted a Christian reporter of promoting sectarianism and sentenced him to five years in prison.
item.dc:creator: By DINA EL-HUSSEINY

item.title: Brazil: Polio Virus Detected in Sewage
item.description: For the first time since 1994, the polio virus has been detected in Brazil, the World Health Organization said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Open Source: Anger and Dismay Online as Egypt Sentences Journalists
item.description: Rights activists, bloggers and journalists in Egypt responded with dismay to a court in Cairo sentencing three reporters to long prison terms for reporting on the unrest in the country last year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Stoppage Time in the World Cup Underscores Soccer’s Strange Rules
item.description: With the stoppage time rule, soccer, a timed game, actually ends only when the referee decides it has ended.
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Portugal’s Silvestre Varela headed the tying goal past the United States’ Tim Howard during stoppage time in Sunday’s game.

item.title: Challenges to Shiite Establishment Further Threaten the Future of Iraq
item.description: The return of a militia loyal to the cleric Moktada al-Sadr has helped undo a rocky unifying process.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Jailed Woman’s Daughter Also Accused of ‘Stirring Up Trouble’
item.description: One day after her mother was sentenced to more than six years in prison, Liao Minyue was served by the police with a demand to surrender her passport and accused of causing trouble, a lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Liao Minyue received a notice ordering her to surrender her passport.

item.title: Egypt Convicts 3 Journalists; U.S. Is Critical
item.description: Prosecutors had accused the journalists of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood to broadcast false reports of civil strife in order to bring down the government.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Ahmed Abd El Latif/El Shorouk Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The fiancée of Mohamed Fahmy was comforted by a friend on Monday after guilty verdicts were announced in a Cairo courtroom.

item.title: In Iraq’s Sectarian Violence, a Show of Each Side’s Worst
item.description: Iraqi police were said to have killed scores of Sunni insurgents, while militants turned over the bodies of Shiite civilians they had killed, only to bomb the cemetery during their funerals, according to one account.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SUADAD AL-SALHY

item.title: Iraqi Insurgents Secure Control of Border Posts
item.description: The seizing of the crossing raised the specter of the insurgency’s becoming a menace not just to Iraq and Syria, but also to Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Mourners in a village in Kirkuk shouted slogans against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, after the bodies of 15 Shiites were handed over to authorities.

item.title: Targeting Anwar al-Awlaki Was Legal, Justice Department Said
item.description: The Justice Department memo concluded that it would be lawful to target Anwar al-Awlaki for killing if his capture was not feasible.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Beit Kahil Journal: Bedouin Trackers Hunting for Clues to Kidnapped Boys
item.description: A specialized team of 50 is among some 1,000 soldiers conducting a sweeping search for three missing Israeli teenagers.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Israeli Army’s trackers unit of Bedouin citizens searched for the three teenagers who were kidnapped on June 12.

item.title: Bomb Injures at Least Five in Lebanon
item.description: An official said at least five people had been wounded when a car bomb exploded near a cafe south of Beirut where people had gathered to watch World Cup matches.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Palestinian Freed in 2011 Is Charged by Israel in a Killing
item.description: Ziad Awad and his son were charged in the death of an Israeli police commander in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By MYRA NOVECK and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Poll Finds Dissatisfaction Over Iraq
item.description: Dissatisfaction with the president’s conduct of foreign policy has shot up among members of both parties in the last month, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DALIA SUSSMAN
item.media:description: Most Americans disapprove of the way President Obama is handling foreign policy, a poll found.

item.title: How the Poll Was Conducted
item.description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 20 to June 22 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States.

item.title: Fouad Ajami, Commentator and Expert in Arab History, Dies at 68
item.description: Mr. Ajami, an academic and commentator on Middle East affairs, strove to put Arab history into a larger perspective and often said terrorism was one result of Muslim rage over losing power to the West in the 17th century.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Diplomatic Note Promises Immunity From Iraqi Law for U.S. Advisory Troops
item.description: The immunity, granted in a diplomatic note from the Iraqi government, is similar to a guarantee rejected by the Obama administration in 2011.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Israel Strikes Syria After Youth Is Killed
item.description: The Israeli military said it had targeted nine Syrian Army positions, including a headquarters and launching areas. The extent of any damage or casualties was not clear.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the Golan Heights after an Israeli teenager was killed by fire from Syria.

item.title: World Cup Displays a Region’s Old Passions and Its New Wealth
item.description: The arrival in Brazil of more than 200,000 fans from Latin America exemplifies one of the region’s most profound shifts: the rise of the middle class.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colombian fans celebrated in São Paulo, Brazil, when their team scored against Ivory Coast. Colombia has qualified for the next round of the World Cup.

item.title: Claim of Fraud in Afghan Vote Leads Official to Step Down
item.description: The official stepped down a day after the candidate Abdullah Abdullah leaked tapes said to portray the official discussing ways to rig the presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ziaulhaq Amarkhil, the top election official, resigned on Monday over accusations that he was colluding with a presidential candidate Ashraf Ghani.

item.title: Preacher Challenges Pakistani Leaders
item.description: Thousands in Islamabad awaited the return of Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri on Monday, ready to reignite a protest movement, but the Pakistani authorities diverted his plane.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
